Really well designed and very fair puzzle game with a lot of character and a lot of fun. It's hard to explain how it feels but Valve has this approach to design that feels "caring". You can never soft-lock yourself in a puzzle, they streamline annoyances with some slight of hand magic, they set up rules just to let you have the satisfaction of breaking them. It's an amazing feat of game design and you should absolutely play it.

Just a heads up, some people not as used to the FPS genre might get some motion sickness. My dad can't play the game for extended periods of time. If this is you, play in small bursts and drink a lot of water.

今天通关了一和二，我来讲一下~
说实话这游戏是我在年底促销时候喜加一，本来就是充库不打算玩，在前天偶然情况下我就下载玩玩。说实话这游戏难度适当，可以说老少皆宜，半条命风格浓厚（风格老粉）。
作为boss的机器人有时候能戳中你的萌点，非常铁憨憨，当二通关后的过场动画跳到炮台时我以为boss骗我，结果.....只是放音乐，每次最后的音乐真的是莫名好听，像是童谣。
如果你实在在家想我一样憋疯的话就玩玩这个游戏，保证物超所值！

[h2]故事深度[/h2]
似乎能写一篇长文来解析解析。反正很棒就对了。

[h2]游戏内容[/h2]
开创了传送门这个新梗。解谜设计精巧、元素合理、动作流畅。[spoiler]似乎还有不少彩蛋的样子。[/spoiler]没深入玩过 1 代，但 2 代的质感让人一眼就喜欢上了。
唯一的遗憾是没找到小伙伴来一起解双人关卡，不然游戏乐趣又上一个台阶。

[h2]艺术设计[/h2]
精致，略显可爱。配音满分。

传送门就是带领我喜欢上解谜游戏的系列。绝对的推荐。

Absolutly must have for Portal 1 owners. Complexity of tasks, humor, story - its just epic.

Portal 2 managed to take an excellent first-person, physics-based puzzle game and covert it into a masterpiece. Half-Life, Left for Dead and Portal show that Valve is (was?) the absolute master in perfecting sequels. Each of the previous games made history and marked a before and an after..
Valve please go back to the roots, even if you have to jump some specific numbers.

Pros
+ Amazing dialogs, black humor and characters; it cannot get better than that.
+ Excellent variety of puzzles and now a lot of new mechanisms are introduced that make the game much less repetitive
+ Also environment changes from test rooms, to huge spaces, to chases. All executed perfectly well.
+ Very clever puzzles. You definitely get the distinct feeling of achievement when you complete the puzzles of especially the later chapters
+ Excellent voice acting, another point that reached perfection.
+ Replayability through co-op, custom maps and challenges.
+ Very engaging story and an amazing end

Cons
- Loading between maps is quite often.
- The game is so good that after completing it, you would definitely ask for more challenges and rooms.
- Some maps look initially so vast that some players may feel overwhelmed.

All-in-all, a true masterpiece, one of the best games ever made. Before the Portal duo it was impossible to imagine a first-person puzzle game, built around physics, becoming a success. This game could be even used for educational purposes. 
Valve, you are breaking our hearts, would you kindly place more focus on game development?
its good
great game

[i]Portal 2[/i] is proof that [i]Valve[/i] has mastered their sequel-making skills, always creating a superior release to what came before, and improving on every front in order to be able to do so.

When starting up this game, I have to admit, I was skeptical. Not that I thought this would be a bad game by any means, but I doubted that it could stand up to one of my favorite gaming experiences yet: [i]Portal[/i]. Although [i]Valve[/i] has always been beyond impressive with sequels, such as with [i]Half-Life 2[/i] and [i]Left 4 Dead 2[/i], both of which are superior to their previous releases, I was still expecting to find one game series in their catalog that didn't solely increase in quality with each release. I'm ecstatic to say, however, that I am in love with this game. This only adds elements and improves what the original [i]Portal[/i] introduced, there is no sort of lazy attempt to steal money from loyal fans, as [i]Portal 2[/i] is well worth what you'll be paying for it. Everything here is pushed to the limit, and there is much more content to take advantage of. There is not only the single-player, which consists of nine very quality chapters, but also co-op, which provides its own five chapters to play with a friend if you choose to do so. Though I have not played the later mode recently, years back I played it with my brother, and we had a lot of fun going through it. There is also plenty of community levels for a player to try out if they are interested, giving more life to this already full experience. This game's single-player took me six hours to beat, as opposed to [i]Portal[/i], which, with some prior experience, took only about two hours.

Though I had played [i]Portal 2[/i] in a co-op manner years ago, I never fully experienced the single-player, which is the main portion of the game, or at least, the central one. Again, I have to say I was skeptical, I wasn't sure if I was gonna be able to enjoy it nearly as much as the first, and so I went in with doubts. As soon as I actually started playing the game, however, I was hooked. This game is extremely funny, which I wasn't expecting, because although [i]Portal[/i] had its moments, it was a more eerie and semi-serious game in tone. This feels like almost the complete opposite, though in the best way possible, as there were many points that I just laughed or had to crack a smile as I became invested in these two (or more if you count prerecorded beings) very fleshed out characters that had extreme wit and conflict that just works. The game doesn't try too hard, it gives you just enough humor to keep you invested, but never to a point where you will be annoyed. The new, decrepit environments and out-of-bounds areas that were mostly absent from [i]Portal[/i] really help to flesh out the world, and the backstory behind Aperture Science helps one to better understand the facility they inhabit. The new additions to puzzles and masterful craftsmanship of the many levels here make not only an excellent game, but one superior to [i]Portal[/i] in almost every single way.

[i]Portal 2[/i] is another masterpiece created by [i]Valve[/i], one that I'm surprised that I love as much as I do. This game is unbelievably cinematic and charming, it is awe-inspiring just how engrossed one can get in the dialogue, and invested in the truly groundbreaking puzzle gameplay. [i]Portal 2[/i] also feels so much more alive than a majority of games, and the only characters besides the silent protagonist, [i]Chell[/i], are robots, which speaks volumes on how intricate and well thought out these characters and their dialogue are. The game only gets better and better as it progresses, and when you already think the game has reached its peak, it surprises you with something that just makes it that much better.

[b][RATING: 9.8/10][/b]
